mapped_songs.post_title: Suicidal, depression, anxiety and self harm songs
mapped_songs.comment_text:
This is my story(Barely 12 years old):
My dad left when I was 4 and I didn't realize what he did was painful until I was 6. Then when I was 7, my mom was diagnosed with cancer. My depression started there because I didn't see her a lot, she was in and out of the hospital. My mom survived cancer and I started having weight problems. I got bullied a lot in elementary school but I didn't tell anybody. I ate because I was hurting, I had nobody. Then my best friend in my neighborhood moved away. That felt like a punch in the stomach. When I was 11 I got into middle school and I was emotionally/verbally abused by my grandmother from August 2017 to July 2018. From August 2017 to February of 2018 I was suicidal and had 2 failed suicide attempts. I'm now in a program at my school where I am learning two years ahead and it's a lot of pressure on me. I've been wanting to get out of that program for 1 month now. But my mom said no and now she is verbally abusing me. This still happens everyday but luckily I have my 3 best friends by my side. You probably won't read all of this but if you did... thank you so much!

7 months later(12 almost 13): WTF 2K LIKES!? And all of the replies and support from people makes me so happy and and helps me realize there are good people in the world! Thank you to the people who wrote some of the replies. You guys helped me through this and I'm doing so much better! I will try and subscribe to all of you as a thank you!

1 year later(13 years old): Holy shit. 3.7k likes, I can't believe this! This is... amazing
I ant to thank all of you, all of you were there when some other people should have been, I love you all!

Almost 2 years later (9/1/2020) 14 years old: Damn. I'm back here for reasons I feel horrible about. My life had gotten worse but now I know I have people to help me and I know that I can fight through this. Again thank you everyone.

Over 2 years later (6/21/2021) 14 turning 15 in less than a month: Holy crap 5.7k likes and 480 replies y'all, thank you so much for the overwhelming amount of support, I am going into my second year of high school in August, I am doing so much better now, I have a lot of friends who love and care for me and mentally I'm doing great. I am 2 years clean of self harm and I am grateful. Take my story as an example, things do get better. They really do. Thank you again for the support. And to the people who are in the place I was listening to this song on the daily, you are loved for who you are. f not by your family and friends, then by me. You will get through this.

mapped_songs.comment_text:
Hey everyone!
I have been hesitating whether or not I should talk about this, but I guess it‚Äôs good if you guys know why I‚Äôve been absent.^^ The truth is I have been feeling quite bad for a while now. Not physically (although I did bite my tongue a few weeks ago so bad that I couldn‚Äôt eat normal for a week xD), but mentally. I did suffer from depressions already many years ago and they have come back to me kind of like waves. Some months, even years I felt better, others I felt really bad again. When I was in my teens I even got to a point where I became suicidal, but thank God that‚Äôs over for good. Especially because of Carina, since she came into my life I have never thought about suicide anymore, ever.^^ The depression stuff never really went away though, and in the past one or two years it has slowly crept back into my head, first I barely realized it but the past months it became very obvious. My mistake was that I tried to tell myself that I‚Äôm not depressed and I didn‚Äôt do what I should have done, which is to open up, let it out, and not trying to ‚Äúbe strong‚Äù, because it only makes you weaker in the end. Depression also has that really annoying side effect that it kills all your creativity, energy, willpower, all of it. I sat down many times at the keyboard and just stared at my fingers. I had nothing, there was not even the spark of an inspiration. That‚Äôs also why I didn‚Äôt make a new song for so long, I simply couldn‚Äôt. Not until I finally had the inspiration for this song right here, a sad, emotional song. And it took a long time for that. This is also what happened to me 5-6 years ago, and it helped me to feel better (I‚Äôm talking about the old songs like Death Dance, Beyond the Veil etc.). Anyway‚Ä¶ making this song was really important, I feel like it‚Äôs the first step I‚Äôm doing forward again towards the light and away from the darkness. So I‚Äôm sorry that I was gone for so long, but at least now you know why. Please don‚Äôt be surprised if there will be some more dark songs than usual at the moment, I just think I need to let them out, it‚Äôs kind of like sucking out a poison for me.

I hope you‚Äôre all in good health and that you have a wonderful day, whatever you‚Äôre doing and wherever you are. =) Please don‚Äôt worry about me, as I said the fact that I made this song is the first step of healing, so the worst is behind. =)
Treat each other well and I‚Äôll see you soon!
mapped_songs.ananki_reasoning: The human explicitly describes suffering from depression that comes in waves, feeling 'quite bad' mentally for a while. The song 'Hurt Myself' by Ekoh directly aligns with this depressive state and self-harmful thought patterns. While 'Night - Contemplative' was mentioned in the post title, the actual emotional context is much deeper and darker - this is about active depression and mental struggle, not peaceful contemplation. The song choice reflects someone processing depressive episodes and internal pain.

mapped_songs.comment_text:
Scarborough is a small town on the coast of England. The "Scarborough Fair" was a popular gathering in Medieval times, attracting traders and entertainers from all over the country. The fair lasted 45 days and started every August 15th. In the 1600s, mineral waters were found in Scarborough and it became a resort town. Today, Scarborough is a quiet town with a rich history. (thanks, Sheryl - Seal Rock, OR)
In Medieval England, this became a popular folk song as Bards would sing it when they traveled from town to town. The author of the song is unknown, and many different versions exist. The traditional version has many more lyrics.
Paul Simon learned about this song when he was on tour in England, where he heard a version by a popular folk singer named Martin Carthy. When Carthy heard Simon & Garfunkel's rendition, he accused Simon of stealing his arrangement. Carthy and Simon did not speak until 2000, when Simon asked Carthy to perform this with him at a show in London. Carthy put his differences aside and did the show.

Martin Carthy learned the song from a Ewan MacColl songbook, and had recorded it on his first album, according to BBC's Patrick Hamphries.

Paul Simon admitted to the July 2011 edition of Mojo magazine: "The version I was playing was definitely what I could remember of Martin's version, but he didn't teach it to me. Really, it was just naivety on my part that we didn't credit it as his arrangement of a traditional tune. I didn't know you had to do that. Then later on, Martin's publisher contacted me and we made a pretty substantial monetary settlement that he was supposed to split with Martin, But unbeknown to me, Martin got nothing."
The lyrics are about a man trying to attain his true love. In Medieval times, the herbs mentioned in the song represented virtues that were important to the lyrics. Parsley was comfort, sage was strength, rosemary was love, and thyme was courage.
This was not released as a single until 1968, when it was used in the Dustin Hoffman movie The Graduate. It is on the soundtrack.
Before Simon & Garfunkel got to it, Bob Dylan used the lines, "Remember me to one who lives there, she once was a true love of mine" in his 1963 song "Girl From The North Country."
"Scarborough Fair" and "Canticle" are 2 songs that are sung simultaneously to create this piece. The first and last verses are "Scarborough Fair," but lines from "Canticle" alternate after the first line of the other verses, so "On the side of a hill in a deep forest green" and "Tracing of sparrow on snow-crested ground" are from "Canticle."
This song is often listed as "Scarborough Fair/Canticle." On The Paul Simon Songbook, a little known 1965 UK album of Simon-solo demos, there is a song called "The Side Of a Hill." "The Side Of a Hill" was reworked into the Canticle part of "Scarborough Fair." (thanks, Jesse - Roanoke, VA)
With its implicit anti-Vietnam War message, this was used in The Wonder Years TV series in a scene where Kevin Arnold embraces Winnie Cooper while the song was played at the end of the episode. In the show, Winnie's brother had been killed in Vietnam. (thanks, Marciliano - Fortaleza, Brazil)
mapped_songs.ananki_reasoning: The comment provides historical context about Scarborough Fair as a Medieval gathering place and folk tradition, emphasizing the passage of time from a vibrant 45-day fair in Medieval times to 'today, Scarborough is a quiet town with a rich history.' This framing evokes longing for a bygone era and the bittersweet nature of historical memory. The mention of 'Bards would sing it' reinforces the folk tradition aspect - a song passed down through generations that carries the weight of history and collective memory. This combination of historical storytelling and folk music tradition strongly suggests a nostalgic, wistful emotional quality rather than purely informational content.
